elements.2211.03183_5f22c9a0e7c49f25849c2b00758f7: A recent popular approach to out-of-distribution (OOD) detection is based on a self-supervised learning technique referred to as
elements.2211.03183_af5a87e501af8de99ee614fef0f8a: There are two main variants of contrastive learning, namely instance and class discrimination, targeting features that can discriminate between different instances for the former, and different classes for the latter
elements.2211.03183_89ab168bdd9d7eb509130ba9c720f: In this paper, we aim to understand the effectiveness and limitation of existing contrastive learning methods for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_9975ee96978f9bb0389cde1b695d8: First, we systematically study the performance difference between the instance discrimination and supervised contrastive learning variants in different OOD detection settings
elements.2211.03183_4d4d6818b1b228b80f320d6df37b7: Second, we study which in-distribution (ID) classes OOD data tend to be classified into
elements.2211.03183_8c2d72e0ed21ad3720593209773fb: Finally, we study the spectral decay property of the different contrastive learning approaches and examine how it correlates with OOD detection performance
elements.2211.03183_b6efe09900e5264a1d06a3ab8b7f7: In scenarios where the ID and OOD datasets are sufficiently different from one another, we see that instance discrimination, in the absence of fine-tuning, is competitive with supervised approaches in OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_dd27833c2d9f2fc5b15fb400a861e: We see that OOD samples tend to be classified into classes that have a distribution similar to the distribution of the entire dataset
elements.2211.03183_ba75ceb0ee7b72802f96461ce828e: Furthermore, we show that contrastive learning learns a feature space that contains singular vectors containing several directions with a high variance which can be detrimental or beneficial to OOD detection depending on the inference approach used.
elements.2211.03183_3ab73aa113fd484c51917842bbf08: In recent years, neural networks have been increasingly deployed for prediction tasks
elements.2211.03183_6d20c6775f8a7c661cebf7a3bd710: However, they still make erroneous predictions when exposed to inputs from an unfamiliar distribution
elements.2211.03183_d489df526095aa892a7b939ddba2d: This poses a significant obstacle to the deployment of neural networks in safety-critical applications
elements.2211.03183_e01ec014aae429ac304a9be0edb2b: Therefore, for applications in these domains, it is necessary to be able to distinguish in-distribution (ID) data from data belonging to a different distribution on which the neural network was trained (OOD data).
elements.2211.03183_871da697e0984bdced250cecbdd18: The problem of detecting such inputs is generally referred to as
elements.2211.03183_c7ef5a74ad51c6b3577c30f37782b: (OOD) detection, outlier detection, or anomaly detection
elements.2211.03183_9e5c3e5aa940e01492fd52b069f83: Recent studies have shown that a type of self-supervised learning referred to as
elements.2211.03183_60675edc553220c715ed72409f230: can learn a feature space that is able to capture the features of an input
elements.2211.03183_707e89e6de38530c06ab6680da0f3: The two main types of contrastive learning approaches are referred to as unsupervised instance discrimination and supervised contrastive learning/supervised class discrimination
elements.2211.03183_fe4b8899afb34143fa733e91051e4: The former works by bringing together the features of the different views of the same data point close together in the feature space enabling discrimination between different instances
elements.2211.03183_3eaae3e393fafb4baddc9f3abf285: Instead, supervised contrastive learning brings data points belonging to the same class close together in feature space, which enables discrimination between data points belonging to different classes
elements.2211.03183_5fb3bbbd82dba2a9fceee7218c269: In light of the variety of contrastive learning approaches used in practice, it is difficult to ascertain which properties of contrastive learning are beneficial to OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_86e5f7abf2689c543026bb55ae07c: In this work, we aim to understand the effectiveness and limitations of existing contrastive learning methods for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_4f1ab681b85c8114da0f97e3874fe: We systematically study the performance difference of the instance discrimination and supervised contrastive learning variants in different OOD detection settings (Section
elements.2211.03183_b5aa2f3ea618ed936c13bcc4dc2be: We investigate which ID classes OOD data tend to be classified into.
elements.2211.03183_b3192113d0ddb78cc25347be3fe9b: We analyze the spectral decay property of the different contrastive learning approaches and how it correlates with OOD detection performance
elements.2211.03183_29a64919a0f15a3ddd39847b5779b: The spectral decay indicates how many different directions of high variance are present in the feature space and is related to the feature space compression
elements.2211.03183_ace4f885b3b72403dbce514e83df4: This involves designing a fair training setup, categorizing the difficulty of OOD detection based on whether ID and OOD datasets are semantically similar (near-OOD) or unrelated (far-OOD), as well as comparing the OOD detection performance using established metrics (Section
elements.2211.03183_3d102567fab228406d9ce957a4259: Our main findings and contributions are summarized below: The key contributions of the paper are as follows:
elements.2211.03183_7aab0427944d5d6129d951067ffc2: We perform experiments that show unsupervised instance discrimination, in the absence of fine-tuning, is well-suited to far-OOD detection, where it can be competitive with supervised approaches but ineffective at near-OOD detection (Section
elements.2211.03183_69b6ceddc3fa4d6303225f0abe821: We analyze the classification of OOD samples and see that they tend to be classified into classes that have a distribution similar to the distribution of the entire dataset
elements.2211.03183_38b34006a3dc4f0d81f9dbb961932: This suggests that similar to the phenomena seen in deep generative models, discriminative models assign OOD samples to classes where the latent features capture non-class discriminatory information rather than class-discriminatory information
elements.2211.03183_caad6ec09034c0fda98796b52ee00: We show that contrastive learning learns a feature space that contains singular vectors containing several directions with a high variance which can be detrimental or beneficial to OOD detection depending on the inference approach used (Section
elements.2211.03183_84b64a964bd388fe588eaea49027f: Most OOD detection methods use the features obtained from a classification network trained with the supervised cross-entropy loss
elements.2211.03183_d77632044073f267326c1d4bc7f4e: These classification networks learn decision boundaries that discriminate between the classes in the training set
elements.2211.03183_984ed56541c2097ecc53d9a0b7f33: However, using a conventional cross-entropy loss does not incentivize a network to learn features beyond the minimum necessary to discriminate between the different classes and therefore may not be well suited for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_e6b49749f3ee14ef9a8d2ef5ce25a: An alternative to using classification networks for learning is contrastive learning
elements.2211.03183_25a2b22e1ac2f36ef2e044026efc1: The idea of contrastive learning is to learn an encoder
elements.2211.03183_f668eb642055762063c8633bb972a: denotes the parameters of the encoder, to extract the necessary information to distinguish between similar and other samples
elements.2211.03183_79607e0d55a8d536bbdd4f256f12e: denote the sets of positive samples of
elements.2211.03183_44f1ae1e1ff56ab75ef2373cccca3: The goal of contrastive loss is to learn features of
elements.2211.03183_86c1eab798d1f762c634ca9bf0e43: The most common form of similarity measure between features
elements.2211.03183_0127334ebd8f7c1c664c7f0829d0e: is given by the cosine similarity as given in Eqn.
elements.2211.03183_9bad48a0a3e09f1ebd782267e0c33: The first type of contrastive loss considered in this paper is the Momentum Contrast (Moco) loss
elements.2211.03183_b2576082cec21c3dc2a4a14695754: , where the objective relates to the task of instance discrimination and utilizes two different encoders, a query encoder
elements.2211.03183_9ee9f179728bdf9655f8ebf2fdf9e: The parameters of the query encoder are updated using traditional backpropagation, whilst the parameters of the key encoder are an exponentially weighted average of the parameters of the query encoder, shown by Eqn.
elements.2211.03183_f45b0f8e1cbbbaf1c35949f2ed81a: are parameters of the query encoder, and
elements.2211.03183_ab3f453b3bada701464f33e91ff44: are the parameters of the key encoder before and after the update respectively
elements.2211.03183_bb74c826b15d42fe1099206f625c8: The setup for the training process is as follows
elements.2211.03183_005bbdb5a8a927d3694461394fc99: are separate augmentation operators sampled from the same family of augmentations
elements.2211.03183_0c1b7525cdb6d82e00ba33fce8671: Query data points are passed through a query encoder to obtain query features
elements.2211.03183_d01861a4cc1a34ec42c02d7737b39: and key data points are passed through the key encoder to obtain the key features
elements.2211.03183_7912e2c571c48c89b7a339a0a107e: is the positive key for each query
elements.2211.03183_4c00e3aabb4abe3860cbb14434334: are previous outputs of the key encoder which were saved in a queue and
elements.2211.03183_c1e9f006e6b587c8fdc22ed0f2d33: The second type of contrastive loss considered in this paper is the Supervised Contrastive (SupCLR) loss
elements.2211.03183_67c1dbe4f0694d56fd9272f491a40: The SupCLR loss is a generalization of the instance discrimination loss which can deal with an arbitrary number of positives samples to enable contrasting samples in a class-wise manner instead of an instance-wise manner
elements.2211.03183_9154121bf7a1bf5bb85a1e2816a7f: In this case, all the data points in the same class as the query
elements.2211.03183_3fa68b0b3dc02afbf92d81e9f9b6a: whilst data points in a different class as the query are treated as negative samples
elements.2211.03183_fbeedb73b410cc923c1d37fb1fea0: The SupCLR loss only requires using a single encoder
elements.2211.03183_aeefae306de5615b5d60ed5287cc3: to obtain features for the queries
elements.2211.03183_f6b62bff2de63bbcab506242fe3ea: The SupCLR contrastive loss is then given by Eqn.
elements.2211.03183_b091efebf2b3a34d2e9963cc2f969: is the set of indices of all positives keys of
elements.2211.03183_7f62bbd163a61de9d0383579589dc: which are present in the batch, and
elements.2211.03183_ab9ae607a6c68db34877c50c478ce: is the set of all indices in the batch excluding
elements.2211.03183_1e5b8edef220e2c23bb671deffe4c: Intuitively, the instance discrimination loss learns the features in each instance which makes it different from other instances whilst also being invariant to data augmentation, whilst the SupCLR loss learns the features in common between different instances of the same class.
elements.2211.03183_b92c2a5c0c9ef42bcb881034ab83e: In this section, we discuss the experimental setup that we use throughout this work.
elements.2211.03183_8c2d566080d10481d72754bd3e1ee: We study OOD detection for the following ID dataset
elements.2211.03183_9987866b8e43fa86f6a02653593ec: We use both simple grayscale dataset pairs and more complex RGB dataset pairs for the task
elements.2211.03183_3f953784e78907f07abf1a3f5fc6c: For the grayscale dataset case which uses MNIST, FashionMNIST, and KMNIST, one of the datasets is defined as
elements.2211.03183_1e711b65d32edaa273a2e47e8f43d: whilst the other datasets are defined as
elements.2211.03183_1f45fed3cfc2a7c24a11efe302b86: For the RGB datasets, we use CIFAR-10, CIFAR100 as well as SVHN and follows the same procedure where one dataset is defined as
elements.2211.03183_a495b4d0ed7d60cc94d1f10a16def: whilst the others are defined as
elements.2211.03183_7196d85b21bb5fc3a788f932bcd69: Similar to Winkens et al, we use the class-wise confusion log probability (CLP) as a measure of the difficulty of an OOD detection task
elements.2211.03183_2469113525c09f5c53428b16a8117: As described in Winkens et al, CLP is based on the probability of a classifier confusing OOD data with ID data
elements.2211.03183_ab76d47a1d2232bc813d5d13d1dc9: This involves computing an estimate of the expected probability of a test OOD sample
elements.2211.03183_2ef340e2d508dbe1b1123f259f14d: being predicted to be an ID class
elements.2211.03183_1da50ab19a5f4458248dc1bca16eb: refers to the probability that the
elements.2211.03183_824120d99f3b28ec0f9e2cf5dab9d: The class-wise confusion log probability (CLP) of ID class
elements.2211.03183_6e652ef043d7631d016747db76f8a: being the test samples belonging to the OOD dataset
elements.2211.03183_c731bb562fafbe65519f58165c389: The distance between the dataset pairs is defined by the min-max bounds on the CLP (lowest CLP value to highest CLP value for the dataset pair)
elements.2211.03183_0bfeebd9d192c35800df377c6de5f: In our work, we use 3 Resnet-18 models to calculate
elements.2211.03183_1abba0fcf8c70374a3f9b22a7f480: For further details on the Confusion Log probability, see Winkens et al
elements.2211.03183_4ebf596a70ed64a77b83a76685eaa:

elements.2211.03183_deb943420ebd17424069d4c73e3fe: The min-max bounds of the CLP for the different dataset pairs are given in Table
elements.2211.03183_846e200f5e38bcb283fe3e6debe04: For the purpose of categorizing the different dataset pairs, we label pairs that have both values for the bounds of the CLP above 6.5 as a far-OOD dataset pair, below 6.5 as near-OOD dataset pair, and dataset pairs which have bounds that have a value above and below 6.5 as a near
elements.2211.03183_d036523da3aaa28d2d3579442c801: The CLP values were chosen by hand so as to separate the datasets and enable comparison.
elements.2211.03183_93e02de05e6714429af4d33883d2e: We measure the quality of OOD detection using the established metrics for this task, which are the AUROC, AUPR and the FPR at 95
elements.2211.03183_c3249d9bf8b36e7753f2026913015: For the AUPR, we treat OOD examples as the positive class
elements.2211.03183_d6dcbded71b3716cf715f6628b915: Unless otherwise stated, metrics reported in this work are obtained based on 8 repeat readings.
elements.2211.03183_a26bccb8fafb14688a73a5b7da517: Experiments were conducted using 2 Tesla P100-PCIE-16GB with 28 CPUs using Pytorch Version 1.7.1 and Pytorch Lightning Version 1.2.3
elements.2211.03183_da16b6b365cdaccc84c77ea726f15: We adopt a Resnet-50 as the encoder
elements.2211.03183_5052280bdc53a207f41681b5ecbf2: for all the different models with a fixed-dimensional output dimensionality of 128-D with the outputs being l2 normalized
elements.2211.03183_ca3a61216daacb926c04a26af7350: For the case of the classification network, also referred to as the Cross-Entropy (CE) model, the output of the Resnet-50 encoder is followed by an additional fully connected layer with an output dimensionality equal to the number of classes in the ID training data
elements.2211.03183_a66ca63aeaf20556b8bfb480879e8: For the case of the Moco model, both the query encoder and the key encoder have the same architecture
elements.2211.03183_779cd2057a73d5d500fbf980b7f52: All models are trained for 300 epochs with a batch size of 256, using the SGD optimizer with a learning rate of
elements.2211.03183_6b35c5efe038707fe82bc54b9e24c: , optimizer momentum of 0.9 and weight decay of 1
elements.2211.03183_20a8987a160f6afe7b38d053019e8: , queue size of 4096, and an encoder momentum
elements.2211.03183_1cacc8b2991a7d47ca06530a1e2e6: Furthermore, both the Moco and SupCLR model use a softmax temperature
elements.2211.03183_330e6af60159004aec330efe825a5: For data augmentation, we use random crop and resize (with random flip), color distortion (for the RGB datasets), and Gaussian blur.
elements.2211.03183_9c913140420a7b35167d53d37d2b1: Instance discrimination is effective for Far-OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_e0cd6fea1a0d93f7012a397f057fa: We hypothesized that as instance discrimination requires being able to distinguish each individual sample from one another, the model trained using instance discrimination will output features
elements.2211.03183_b52b31a004b0227d1f15360fbb289: which retains a large amount of information about the input
elements.2211.03183_f08068ff98400583fecd02ae5a71f: By retaining a large amount of information regarding an input, the Moco model could achieve high OOD performance
elements.2211.03183_20f7fe3c311c6b12cfeb6a4a48eed: This depends on how semantically similar the ID and OOD points are to one another and what information the inference approach focuses on.
elements.2211.03183_3cde4ca5b597fad34ea5a9bb59809: To investigate when the instance discrimination loss is effective, we compare the Moco model with the SupCLR and CE model to see the difference when using training labels in the training process
elements.2211.03183_bd7d1476fb0bfb43b769be11b9c37: Furthermore, we look at the effect of supervised labels during inference by examining the OOD detection performance of different models across several different dataset pairs using two different inference approaches
elements.2211.03183_a3d2e4d6a92d1788ea9a04bc5ffcd: The inference approaches used are the Mahalanobis Distance with class-dependent covariance matrices
elements.2211.03183_f70a65d26e038ebdb17dbf9888224: which use class labels, as well as the kernel density estimation (KDE) approach which does not use class labels.

elements.2211.03183_b1bbf6e3579b794afd59f47804bba: For the case of the KDE approach, Table
elements.2211.03183_efbf568de118b2c1c3aad6e0cccfc: shows that the Moco model consistently performed worse
elements.2211.03183_08ad1561643f6dbafa72443d3494e: This showed that in the absence of any training labels, the instance discrimination training makes it difficult to group ID data together and therefore leads to poor OOD detection performance
elements.2211.03183_9a3869d96cc4c3ad57a2c0b04e95f: Furthermore, the CE model is generally the highest performing model across the metrics, even outperforming SupCLR
elements.2211.03183_59084382dda6397bc085b84b31482: This shows that in the absence of labels during the inference process, the CE model is best able to group the data in the feature space such that the OOD test data are farther than the ID test data from the ID training data points
elements.2211.03183_74ca7666c24c65a8841763ac90691: For the task of OOD detection using the Mahalanobis Distance inference approach, Table
elements.2211.03183_7e825eaaf1d61f4aa4aa846bea906: shows that for the grayscale datasets, the Moco model is competitive with the CE model and the SupCLR model achieves the best results
elements.2211.03183_53fca018490e0ee6b48b507f609fc: This shows that for the grayscale datasets, the features learned from contrastive learning are able to compete with or outperform the CE model
elements.2211.03183_b1f0c6a5eb41afab90f0317897d0c: However, for the case of the RGB datasets, the Moco approach outperforms the CE model on the CIFAR10-SVHN dataset pair and outperforms SupCLR on the CIFAR100-SVHN dataset pair, both of which are categorized as far-OOD
elements.2211.03183_f8a6475c3f14eb17f7dd85370d502: In contrast, for the case of CIFAR10-CIFAR100 (near-OOD) and CIFAR100-CIFAR10 (near
elements.2211.03183_34b8e43d5532a9504c761caf3f446: far-OOD), Moco performs significantly worse than both supervised approaches
elements.2211.03183_e44b160e4e2f9887b6decedbc5ffa: This suggests that for far-OOD detection tasks, it can be beneficial to use the unsupervised instance discrimination training to perform OOD detection, although, class discriminatory information obtained from supervised training is important for high performance in near-OOD detection settings
elements.2211.03183_2f96b60ecd90ddbe7f8157af49848: Furthermore, it can be seen that using class labels to group the features during the inference process leads to a larger improvement in the contrastive learning models compared to the CE model as shown by a larger improvement in the contrastive models when using the Mahalanobis Distance inference approach rather than KDE.
elements.2211.03183_b304c22d201895ecdb94182ae1977: OOD samples are classified into classes that learn non-class discriminatory statistics
elements.2211.03183_edb5b673077556f28c106f027f804: We hypothesized that the more similar a class distribution is to the distribution of the entire dataset, which we refer to as the overall distribution, the more likely it is that OOD data will be misclassified as that class
elements.2211.03183_062cdc86450c1cf67fa1eb3eb30ef: The intuition here is that OOD data tends to be misclassified as belonging to the least distinctive class
elements.2211.03183_9934ee1d7af6e36a58be370e3d9ac: We believe that the similarity of a class distribution to the overall distribution indicates how much the features of a particular class contain non-class discriminatory information, which indicates how distinctive the class distribution is.
elements.2211.03183_ac260d7cfbfdaccdbfcbb367b3305: To quantify the dissimilarity of the class distribution to the overall distribution, we approximated the class distribution as well as the overall distribution by Gaussian distributions and calculated the KL divergence between the overall distribution and class distribution,
elements.2211.03183_6f1e2dd997d078670261da87c29d4: Furthermore, the expected Overall-Class KL as shown by Eqn.
elements.2211.03183_76e3e69358566aad1e06d97176409: was calculated for the contrastive models to see whether there was any difference in this metric between the two approaches.
elements.2211.03183_74d233b5a1f4ea124a8265056e91b: , it can be seen that there is a negative correlation between the KL divergence and the class-wise confusion log probability
elements.2211.03183_689ced89aba7d0d2eb32a81c7f4cb: This supports our hypothesis that the more dissimilar the class distribution is to the overall distribution, the more likely OOD data points will be misclassified into that ID class
elements.2211.03183_ffda55c649e285e6ce9d442138413: This behavior agrees with the phenomena seen in deep generative models where OOD data points are given high likelihoods by arbitrarily having low compressed lengths and being similar to the non-class discriminatory statistics of the data
elements.2211.03183_255b9d3b077c9f4e3571e09cf922b: against CLP scatter plots for other dataset pairs can be seen in Appendix
elements.2211.03183_a9edd01a526a752461cb40485fc4e: , it can be seen that the Moco model had expected Overall-Class KL values smaller than the SupCLR model
elements.2211.03183_8d4af28b934078756ddd02f9a97c2: We believe this explains why the Moco model performs poorly on the near-OOD detection pairs such as CIFAR10-CIFAR100 and CIFAR100-CIFAR10
elements.2211.03183_0dd83ccdf354d93a802fcec16d182: For the case of Moco where there is a small KL divergence between the overall and class distributions, it indicates that the features from Moco capture general non-class discriminatory information which is common in the ID dataset
elements.2211.03183_56f3dd7f19b6ad288b8a983a41542: This can make near-OOD detection difficult as the OOD dataset is likely to have similar non-class discriminatory statistics in common with the ID dataset
elements.2211.03183_77537347c5ca01c31ca13ffc976e1: However, in the case of a far-OOD detection situation, the non-class discriminatory statistics are sufficiently different between the two datasets to enable Moco to effectively detect OOD data.
elements.2211.03183_66add36d97cd831ac397377376616: Number of directions of significant variance
elements.2211.03183_e7d7d3c19a613d06fb59c485882ad: ), contrastive learning results in poorer performance in OOD detection than the traditional CE model when using KDE than when using the Mahalanobis Distance approach
elements.2211.03183_e37077c3ed07014bcac3a1a841629: We claim that this is, at least in part, due to contrastive learning trained models learn a rich feature space with several different directions of high variance
elements.2211.03183_7db7e1e35ce1a196fde2649d649e6: In the situation where KDE is used for inference, having a feature space with several directions of variance is likely to result in the OOD data having similar features to the ID data, leading to the misclassification of OOD data as ID
elements.2211.03183_8b4f37b70e7995f91710fe67f5a9e: However, in the situation where the Mahalanobis Distance inference approach is used, using class labeled data can help to identify which factors of variation are important for class discrimination which can be used to aid in discriminating the ID data from the OOD data.
elements.2211.03183_2196f612e68233f0487de39dc4f35: To quantify how rich a feature space is, we investigated the number of factors of variation in the features by following the procedure taken in Section 5 of Roth et al which involves calculating the spectral decay
elements.2211.03183_5cf1b31a13fc063e602a764558d5b: This involves computing the singular value decomposition (SVD) of the features of the training data, normalizing the sorted spectrum of singular values, and computing the KL-divergence between a D-dimensional discrete uniform distribution and the sorted spectrum of singular values
elements.2211.03183_a146c91d0dd510da19ee2c8004b01: Using this metric, lower values of
elements.2211.03183_9340e75b91a8482ee1610170d9871: indicate more directions of significant variance.
elements.2211.03183_ec8ab79396f45dcbb1d840792174c: , it can be seen that both contrastive models generally have lower values of
elements.2211.03183_afa3ff141b9446e0b2c4d0c2b0152: than the CE model, with the exception of the CIFAR100 dataset where the CE model has a lower
elements.2211.03183_00264d4cec399da37a3aa71dc000f: As the supervised SupCLR model was able to outperform the supervised CE model on all the datasets in which the SupCLR model had a lower
elements.2211.03183_637f51010af605b0457ec2a171a02: value when using the Mahalanobis Distance, this suggests that having a large number of significant directions of variance is an important property for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_b1db22719e8dc6a96691996f19557: The Moco model consistently has the lowest
elements.2211.03183_177284c379e1af2d33d4e2d4c60db: which indicates its features have the largest number of factors of variation
elements.2211.03183_aeaf32528d60c04367b21354c5708: This is likely due to the difficult task of instance discrimination requiring learning a large number of factors of variation to perform the task
elements.2211.03183_21470f9d0d310e978aa305c57de54: Whereas, the CE and SupCLR models only require learning features needed to discriminate data between different classes resulting in a smaller number of significant factors of variation.
elements.2211.03183_c0b468ff43e9fffb32f389af977c4: Recent approaches in OOD detection can be categorized as calibration-based
elements.2211.03183_271425838b0fcf73bea9d6da3dc4a: Self-supervised learning-based approaches can be split into auxiliary pretext task-based
elements.2211.03183_ed2f220271717800a8c3de68969a5: or approaches that utilize aspects of both auxiliary pretext tasks and contrastive learning
elements.2211.03183_6d73de291cffe510c60e404f7b67c: The contrastive learning approaches vary significantly and our work also falls in the category of investigating contrastive learning for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_e2a895948a43d88223a9728b5b289: Some approaches use instance discrimination-based pretraining followed by fine-tuning with a supervised cross-entropy loss
elements.2211.03183_1bd2293808a8d561c7e3fb8b59029: Both these papers and ours focus on the instance discrimination contrastive learning task, however, our work focuses on instance discrimination in the absence of fine-tuning with a supervised loss
elements.2211.03183_bc15216c0e405d79ef39a7554c897: Other approaches do not use the pretraining followed by fine-tuning paradigm and instead focus on using a supervised contrastive loss for OOD detection when labels are available
elements.2211.03183_4cc34a4c928efba0ba37e3a5840a8: Our work also examines the performance of the supervised contrastive loss for OOD detection, although we use the original supervised contrastive loss for the purpose of analyzing the properties present in contrastive learning which makes it effective for OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_92f31a9f3b51093d2f5524be995b6: Furthermore, our work differs from all the aforementioned work as it is the first to examine the differences between using a supervised contrastive compared to an instance discrimination approach as well as the effect of different inference methods on OOD detection performance.
elements.2211.03183_a673d603c1c97527decf4763ffd6e: In this work, we investigated the effectiveness and limitations of two popular contrastive learning approaches for the problem of OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_558caad056179351dc823ec4295f7: In our work, we saw that:
elements.2211.03183_6eead5ea64acee454ed912ed1790d: Contrastive learning learns a larger number of factors of variation compared to classification networks
elements.2211.03183_dc146466a7b81037837ffd73ec7cd: This can be detrimental to OOD detection performance when using KDE (unsupervised inference) but beneficial when using Mahalanobis distance (supervised inference).
elements.2211.03183_935cf725c2b0f4cd317776fff3aef: Unsupervised instance discrimination learns a richer feature space with a wide variety of factors of variation compared to supervised contrastive learning as shown by analyzing the spectral decay.
elements.2211.03183_59aa27c88c4d0187666f78e188f67: By having a large number of factors of variation, instance discrimination can be more effective than the Cross-Entropy baseline at far-OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_d5a5379f14f8a56a25da3dfd0f601: Despite having a larger number of factors of variation than the supervised contrastive Learning, instance discrimination is ineffective at near-OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_52e424a4a94d9daa3bf2add89d9b2: Instance discrimination is ineffective at near-OOD detection as it leads to a poorer separation between the different classes in the feature space which was shown by having a lower
elements.2211.03183_3e73b54929ae4052886b080712a8e: OOD detection was more difficult when using the unsupervised KDE inference compared to the supervised Mahalanobis Distance
elements.2211.03183_fb29b97c8bfab8b23fea229586086: It was seen that OOD detection was more difficult when using the unsupervised KDE inference compared to the supervised Mahalanobis Distance
elements.2211.03183_0cf98afd60ed7628ad1c0eb71605a: Furthermore, it was seen that when using the Mahalanobis Distance, Moco was able to achieve competitive OOD detection performance with supervised approaches in the task of far-OOD detection but was ineffective at near-OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_188c60373683e0323b642c95769a8: To understand the reason for this behavior we examined what ID class OOD samples would be classified into as well as the spectral decay of the different algorithms
elements.2211.03183_b343328506ae950520a9840570fc2: We saw that OOD samples tended to be classified into classes similar to the overall distribution and thus possess features based on non-class discriminatory statistics
elements.2211.03183_16d03fa6429177503d878aa7e4c96: Therefore to be able to effectively separate ID from OOD data, it is important that the ID classes be effectively clustered away from one another
elements.2211.03183_b2770169bd66a3cd9f17d5c2505db: As a result, the OOD detection was poorer when using KDE compared to Mahalanobis distance as a result of the class labels clustering the ID data further apart from one another
elements.2211.03183_d25ac49580e4ddbc6a667653e7133: Also, Moco was shown to have an Expected KL divergence which was lower than SupCLR which suggests that it learns more non-class discriminatory information compared to SupCLR
elements.2211.03183_464f138fd05b39de4419cd3d83829: We attribute this to the supervised approaches learning a few factors of variation which are mostly related to class-specific information which leads to better clustering of the data whilst Moco learns a large number of factors of variation, as shown by the spectral decay, which can lead to poorer clustering, which makes it ineffective when the ID and OOD data contain similar non-class discriminatory specific statistics.
elements.2211.03183_c226bebd9484c5e02799f74d6e13a: - Relate to the inference approach - Relate to the the factors of variation We attribute this to the supervised approaches learning a few factors of variation which are mostly related to class-specific information which leads to better clustering of the data whilst Moco learns a large number of factors of variation which can lead to poorer clustering, which makes it ineffective when the ID and OOD data contain similar non-class discriminatory specific statistics
elements.2211.03183_b25c11a88a929a6c8a1f77d6a1f57: We saw that OOD samples tended to be classified in the overall distribution and therefore posseses feature which are in common between the different classes and therefore contain non-class discriminatory statistics
elements.2211.03183_85a66b5db963fd565cfcc99538e25: Therefore to be able to effectively separate ID from OOD data, it is important that the ID classes to be effectively clustered away from one another
elements.2211.03183_d4ba67a76bc58ed2851b7ece28c6a: As a result of this, OOD detection was more difficult when using the unsupervised inference KDE inference compared to the supervised Mahalanobis Distance
elements.2211.03183_7e713da7565075a687ae19e00003b: Furthermore, it was seen that when using the Mahalanobis Distance, Moco was able to achieve competitive OOD detection performance with supervised approaches in the task of far OOD detection, however was poorer at near OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_0926ad612e77e664560543de2ff98: We attribute this to the supervised approaches learning a few factors of variation which are mostly related to class-specific information which leads to better clustering of the data whilst Moco learns a large number of factors of variation which can lead to poorer clustering, which makes it ineffective when the ID and OOD data contain similar non-class discriminatory specific statistics.
elements.2211.03183_d38ad472a2830b7729125be03b283: Based on our findings, we present guidelines to practitioners when using contrastive learning for OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_b1b9ae00a87f748fb020f053b5aa4: Using a supervised OOD detection approach is significantly better than using an unsupervised approach
elements.2211.03183_96f08ede80c5bfac3d96fe3830072: Unsupervised instance discrimination is able to be competitive with supervised approaches in the case of far OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_8f5c5434d562644211b4f3aae5456: In a near-OOD setting, a supervised contrastive appraoch is generally better than traditional cross-entropy approach for OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_34207ad7e0a62f703f434b9a0d613: We would also like to point out some limitations of our study
elements.2211.03183_d993b2f7f9ae4f61f8bf54ffb8024: Firstly, we focus on two different contrastive learning methods which uses explicit negatives (e.g
elements.2211.03183_b8f9f96252e2859248a3db190da82: We chose to focus on these two methods as these methods are quite general contrastive learning approaches where the only significant difference is is the use of supervision
elements.2211.03183_7094d4c9985c2b38e5a49a6d52c12: Therefore, comparing the results of the two methods should give an indication of the effect of supervision in OOD detection performance
elements.2211.03183_77552270219a293ae95c5c4061eea: We believe that other methods based on explicit negatives such as the InfoNCE and Triplet losses would also exhibit similar behaviour
elements.2211.03183_4c6b8d1935fdba23ab1194b2dbcde: An avenue of future work could examine the effect of different properties of self-supervised approaches on OOD detection performance
elements.2211.03183_97d889fa822ddd881474cef74cfea: Example of such properties could be whether a self-supervised approach uses explicit negatives or not, as well as the effect of redundancy reduction principle from Barlow Twins
elements.2211.03183_9384c4fff9f79c503563d6804c150: Furthermore, after identifying that OOD samples tend to be allocated to classes that have a distribution similar to the overall distribution, future work could involve investigating whether it is possible to regularise the contrastive loss to prevent each class from being too similar to the overall distribution
elements.2211.03183_b8f75aa0e5d2ace842f3d0ef7712c: This could enable the instance discrimination contrastive loss to learn a rich feature space whilst also learning class-specific semantic features which can improve near-OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_c4c6af3338d9fb4ff28dbb9b88d89: In this work, we investigated the properties of two popular contrastive learning approaches for the problem of OOD detection
elements.2211.03183_aad936f2a2b9295939d4f7d8044b1: From our work we can see that:
elements.2211.03183_d3b17801557443f6387d00968d69a: Contrastive learning learns a larger number of factors of variation compared to classification networks which can be detrimental or beneficial for OOD detection depending on whether the inference approach uses class labels or not.
elements.2211.03183_e4eda49b35282aaeebfa8b9dca2bc: Whilst the unsupervised instance discrimination variation of contrastive learning is able to learn a rich feature space with a wide variety of factors of variation which is effective for the task of far-OOD detection, it is more likely to learn non-class discriminatory statistics which makes it fail at near-OOD detection.
elements.2211.03183_0736c64a90d3015331fe82c8e9311: This research was partially funded by an EPRSC PhD studentship as part of the Centre for Doctoral Training in Future Autonomous and Robotic Systems (grant number EP/L015293/1)
elements.2211.03183_56822e99633e3ddc550ee2e6dd290: RSR is funded by the UKRI Turing AI Fellowship EP/V024817/1.
